load.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a large quantity of something that is carried by a vehicle, person etc
load.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The lorry had shed its load (=the load had fallen off).
The plane was carrying a full load of fuel.
load.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the amount of work that a person or machine has to do
load.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The computer couldn’t handle the load and crashed.
My work load has doubled since Henry left.
They hired more staff in order to spread the load.
Hans has a heavy teaching load this semester.
load.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a problem or worry that is difficult to deal with
load.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: When someone is depressed, the extra load of having financial problems can make the situation worse.
Knowing he was safe was a load off my mind (=I felt less worried).
Coping with ill health was a heavy load to bear.
load.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a quantity of clothes that are washed together in a washing machine
load.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I’ve already done three loads of laundry this morning.
load.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the amount of weight that something is supporting
load.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: It increased the load on the wheels.
load.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: an amount of electrical power that is being produced
load.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to put a large quantity of something into a vehicle or container
load.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It took an hour to load the van.
Will you help me load the dishwasher?
Emma loaded all the groceries into the car.
He loaded the cups onto a tray.
She loaded up the car with camping gear.
load.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to put a necessary part into something in order to make it work, for example bullets into a gun or film into a camera
load.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Did you load it with 200 or 400 film?
Can you load the CD into the player, please?
load.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to put a program into a computer
load.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The program takes a while to load.
To load the file, press the ‘return’ key.
load.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if a ship, aircraft etc loads, goods are put onto it
load.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The first ship to load at the new port was the ‘Secil Angola’.
The boat called at Lerwick to load up with fresh vegetables.
load.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: an amount of goods or people transported on a road vehicle, train, or plane
load.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Rail cars are used to move the bigger loads.
The lorry returned with a load of Spanish apricots.
The plane was carrying a full load of passengers.
load.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the amount of something that a person or organization has to do
load.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The firm’s computers are struggling to cope with the increased load.
The network has to deal with a heavy load of telephone traffic.
load.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: an amount of money charged for managing an INVESTMENT FUND
load.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Because of the 5% load, only $950 of the $1,000 actually gets invested in your name.
The new fund carries a front-end load (=an amount paid when the fund is first started) of 5.5%
load.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to put goods into a road vehicle, train, boat, or plane to be transported
load.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The tankers set off as soon as they have been loaded.
load.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to copy a computer program or file onto a computer
load.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: The new software can be loaded easily onto most machines.
load.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to include most or all of the charges at a particular period during the time that an insurance policy or INVESTMENT FUND is in use
load.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: A lot of personal pension funds are front-end loaded (=make most of their charges when the fund is first started).
